intro: Acacia nigripilosa, commonly known as the black-haired wattle, is a shrub or small tree native to Australia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its compound leaves and yellow flowers. The plant has slender, wiry stems with a distinctive dark reddish-brown color. Its flowers are typically arranged in cylindrical spikes and are pollinated by insects. Acacia nigripilosa is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, making it a resilient species in harsh climates.

It is commonly found in the southwestern region of the state, particularly in areas with sandy or gravelly soils. Acacia nigripilosa plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soils and providing habitat for local wildlife.
